'''Tommy Johnson''' (1896 – November 1, 1956) was an influential [[United States|American]] [[delta blues]] [[musician]], who recorded in the late 1920s, and was known for his eerie [[falsetto]] voice and intricate guitar playing.<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition=
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited
| location= Dubai
| pages= 127–128
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>

==Early life==
Johnson was born near [[Terry, Mississippi]], and moved around 1910 to [[Crystal Springs, Mississippi|Crystal Springs]] where he lived for most of his life.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p398|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography by Cub Koda |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=November 23, 2009}}</ref>
He learned to play the guitar and, by 1914, was supplementing his income by playing at local parties with his brothers Major and LeDell.  In 1916 he married and moved to Webb Jennings' Plantation near [[Drew, Mississippi]], close to the [[Dockery Plantation]].  There he met other musicians including [[Charlie Patton]] and [[Willie Brown (musician)|Willie Brown]].<ref name=trail>[http://www.nps.gov/history/delta/blues/people/tommy_johnson.htm Trail of the Hellhound: Tommy Johnson.<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

==Career==
By 1920 he had become an alcoholic and itinerant musician, based in Crystal Springs but traveling widely around the South, sometimes accompanied by [[Papa Charlie McCoy]].  In 1928 he made his first recordings with McCoy for [[Victor Records]].<ref name="AMG"/>  The recordings included "Canned Heat Blues", in which he sang of drinking [[methanol]] from the cooking fuel [[Sterno]].<ref name="AMG"/> The song features the refrain "canned heat, mama, sure, Lord, killing me." The blues group [[Canned Heat]] took their name from this song.<ref name="AMG"/>  Johnson's "Big Road Blues" inspired Canned Heat's song, "[[On the Road Again (Canned Heat song)|On the Road Again]]". A significantly different version of the song appears as "Canned Heat" on the ''Big Road Blues'' album by [[K. C. Douglas]].

He recorded two further sessions, in August 1928, and for [[Paramount Records]] in December 1929. He did not record again, mistakenly believing that he had signed away his right to record. This resulted in a legal settlement with The [[Mississippi Sheiks]] who had used Johnson's "Big Road Blues" melody in their successful "Stop and Listen". Johnson was party to the copyright settlement, but was too drunk at the time to understand what he had signed to.<ref>Evans, David. ''Tommy Johnson''. Studio Vista (1971), ''p''. 68. ISBN 978-0289701515</ref>

Johnson's recordings established him as the premier [[Delta blues]] vocalist of his day, with a powerful voice that could go from a growl to a falsetto. He was also an accomplished guitarist. His style influenced later blues singers such as [[Robert Nighthawk]] and [[Howlin' Wolf]],<ref name=trail>as well as [[country singer]] [[Hank Williams]] [http://www.nps.gov/history/delta/blues/people/tommy_johnson.htm Trail of the Hellhound: Tommy Johnson<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> whose song "I Asked for Water (She Brought Me Gasoline)" was based on Johnson's "Cool Water Blues".<ref name="AMG"/>  He was a talented composer, blending fragments of folk poetry and personalized [[lyrics]] into set guitar accompaniments to craft striking blues compositions such as "Maggie Campbell".<ref>Barlow, William. ''"Looking Up At Down": The Emergence of Blues Culture''. Temple University Press (1989), p. 42. ISBN 0-87722-583-4.</ref>

To enhance his fame, Johnson cultivated a sinister persona. According to his brother LeDell, he claimed to have [[Deal with the Devil|sold his soul]] to [[the devil]] in exchange for his mastery of the guitar.<ref name=trail>[http://www.nps.gov/history/delta/blues/people/tommy_johnson.htm Trail of the Hellhound: Tommy Johnson <!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name = "Evans22">Evans, David. ''Tommy Johnson''. Studio Vista (1971), ''p''. 22. ISBN 978-0289701515</ref> This story was later also associated with [[Robert Johnson]], to whom Tommy Johnson was unrelated. Tommy Johnson also played tricks with his guitar, playing it between his legs and behind his head, and throwing it in the air while playing.<ref name="AMG"/>

Johnson remained a popular performer in the [[Jackson, Mississippi metropolitan area|Jackson area]] through the 1930s and 1940s, sometimes performing with [[Ishman Bracey]].<ref name="AMG"/> He was highly influential on other performers, partly because he was willing to teach his style and his repertoire. Tommy Johnson's influence on local traditions is discussed by David Evans in ''Tommy Johnson'' and ''''Big Road Blues. Tradition & Creativity in the Folk Blues''.<ref>Evans, David. ''Big Road Blues. Tradition & Creativity in the Folk Blues''. Da Capo (1982). ISBN 0-306-80300-3</ref>

==Death==
He died of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] after playing at a party in 1956.<ref name="AMG"/> He is buried in the Warm Springs Methodist Church Cemetery outside of Crystal Springs, Mississippi.<ref name="AMG"/> In 2001 a headstone was commissioned through the [[Mt. Zion Memorial Fund]], a Mississippi non-profit corporation, by the family of Tommy Johnson and paid for by musician [[Bonnie Raitt]]. The large, granite memorial engraved with Johnson's portrait was not placed on Johnson's grave for several years afterward, however, due to an ongoing dispute between Tommy Johnson's family (led by his niece, Vera Johnson Collins), the owners of farm property encircling the cemetery, and the Copiah County Board of Supervisors in regard to a deteriorated road preventing access to the burial site. This issue was resolved in October 2012, when it was announced that the headstone would reach its final destination on October 26.<ref>{{Cite web | title =Miss. bluesman getting long overdue grave marker publisher =Associated Press | date =October 25, 2012 | url =http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2012/oct/25/miss-bluesman-getting-long-overdue-grave-marker/ | accessdate =October 25, 2012 }}</ref> The headstone had been on public display in the Crystal Springs, Mississippi Public Library since being unveiled on October 20, 2001. On the night of Saturday, February 2, 2013, the headstone was desecrated, apparently smashed by a [[sledge hammer]] or some similar device.<ref>[http://www.pomeroyblues.org/2013/02/03/tommy-johnson-headstone-desecrated/  pomeroyblues.org]</ref>

An annual Tommy Johnson Blues Festival is now held in Crystal Springs, on every third weekend in October. The inaugural edition was held in [[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson]] and Crystal Springs in 2006.<ref>{{Cite web | title =First Annual Tommy Johnson Celebration | work =Programme | publisher =Tommy Johnson Blues Foundation | year =2006 | url =http://www.tommyjohnsonblues.com/images/tommy_johnson.pdf | format =pdf | accessdate =August 31, 2011 }}</ref>

==In fiction==
In the movie ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]'' (2000),  a character named Tommy Johnson is played by [[Chris Thomas King]]. This character describes selling his soul to the devil to play guitar. In the film, Tommy Johnson plays a number of songs originally recorded by blues musician [[Skip James]], and also accompanies the [[Soggy Bottom Boys]], a band consisting of the film's three main protagonists plus Johnson, on "[[Man of Constant Sorrow]]". The story of Tommy Johnson selling his soul to the devil was first told by Tommy Johnson's brother, LaDell Johnson, and reported by David Evans in his 1971 biography of Johnson.<ref name = "Evans22"/> This legend was subsequently transferred to the blues musician [[Robert Johnson]].<ref>Wald, Elijah, 2004, ''Escaping The Delta: Robert Johnson and the Invention of the Blues'', pp. 265–276.</ref>
